description.text: A two position iPad stand. Designed for an iPad generation one, but surely easily adapted for the newer models. It has two holding slots, one for portrait (with captive 30pin charging cable) and one for landscape non-charging viewing. We thought there would be some counterbalance issues due to the weight of the stand vs the tablet, so we incorporated a place to sit a hockey puck for weight. However, it seems to work fine without, so weâ€™re calling that a combination cup holder and car keys/loose change holding slot. Kudos to thingiverse user â€œZaggoâ€ and thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1279 from way back for the idea to arrest movement of the cabling with an undulating underside channel. Our bot is live to the web at www.justin.tv/bot14me2

Print and mount to Replicator
We printed with all standard repG settings, but modified the fill to 10% and the shells to 3

description.text: This is my second ever thing, I wanted to be able to print a keychain when my first 3D printer arrives in a few days.

title: Monoprice Maker Select Plus, Wanhao Duplicator i3 Tool Holder

description.text: After printing Berky93's Tool holder for my Monoprice Select Plus I decided to model my own tool holder for the other side which compliments his perfectly. It holds the rest of the tools that I use for my printer commonly. This holds the nozzle cleaning bit in its little plastic case, a spare SD card, a feeler gauge set, and the long wire filament pusher that came with the printer. It is designed so that no overhang is more than 45 degrees so it should print well without supports. I printed mine with 100% infill out of PLA and it seems to work great! Print it with the "Top" side down so that the pockets for the feeler gauges and bit holder stick up like pillars. Let me know if there are any dimensional inconsistencies with parts you are trying to store, specifically feeler gauge sets. Thanks!

author: SERVANTSGLASSLLC

title: Paddle for C&K; panel mount rocker switches

description.text:
These are paddle switch caps for C&K switches like the kind used on the IMSAI 8080 computer. Use them on your own retrocomputers!

If you search Digikey, you'll find (at least as of June 2017) the right rocker switches, but only one or two with paddle-type caps. The problem is that you can't get them in the colors you want, unless you want black. And I get the feeling from the quantities available that the factory isn't going to make any more once they run out.

This Thing is a paddle switch matching the IMSAI 8080 switch caps, and compatible with the same type of rocker switch, since the switch caps are interchangeable. You can even get the switch without the cap

Examples of switches:

  • NKK: M2018TYW01-HA
  • NKK: M2012TYW01 (without cap)
  • C&K: 7105J1ZQE2

Basically any rocker switch with mounting type "Panel Mount, Flange" and panel cutout size "Rectangular - 28.50mm x 16.00mm". But they all can use the same switch cap.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed with the default 0.35 fast profile in Slic3r PE. I printed on it's side with the split part of the guide to the top. description.text: This is a remix of wrodz's remix of Shii's filament guide for the original Prusa i3 mk2. The objective of this remix was to bring the guide directly above the crossbar in support of keeping the filament spool on rollers behind the printer instead of atop it.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.35 fast

Infill:

10

Notes:

I printed with the default 0.35 fast profile in Slic3r PE. I printed on it's side with the split part of the guide to the top. This didn't layer well, way too much of a cantilever there. I suggest printing with that side DOWN, OR print with supports in the main guide opening.

A light sanding around the opening of the filament guide is recommended to smooth out the path so that it doesn't scrape your filament on the way by. Also as with anything that's designed to snap onto the metal top of the printer, you'll want to trim away any excess that squished out from the first layer.
This was banged out in tinkercad in just a few minutes.

I designed this bracket to allow me to mount a 150mm x 86mm ATX PSU under a (Ikea Lack) table. It should work for a number of different configurations of ATX PSU, with mine having a 120mm fan on the bottom of the PSU.

Printed with supports in its current orientation but you could flip it and use less supports.

Print 2, i.e. 1 for each end of the PSU.

print_settings.Notes:: The print time (17 hours) was for both the top and bottom of the enclosure. I printed it with a PVA raft, hence the rough edges. The 2mm pegs are fragile, be careful when putting everything in the enclosure. I glued the brass standoffs in with 5 minute set epoxy, but I imagine that was overkill. Regular super glue should suffice. Make sure to plug the SATA to USB adapter into the hard drive before putting it in the enclosure.

description.text: A hard drive enclosure designed to be used with most 7 mm, 2.5" hard disk drives or solid states. Assembly will require two, 12 mm, brass standoffs and the corresponding M2.5 or M3 screws. I suggest the use of M2.5 as they were the only ones I tested. It's designed to be used with "https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01HEAC6WS/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1". I am in no way trying to market this brand, it was simply the cheapest option when I was ordering my SATA to USB cable.

title: MP Select Mini Controller Board Fan Mount by NF6X Remix

description.text: After a couple of overheat shut-downs on long print jobs, I needed a main board fan. This fan bracket from NF6X was exactly what I was looking for, but I couldn't find metric standoffs locally, so I just added 16mm spacers to the bracket in FreeCad, with a 1mm chamfer at the base for strength. Printed on my Mini at 0.13125 layer height and 50 percent infill. Then used M3 X 25 screws with lock washers to attach the bracket. The fan is the one recommended in the original, very quiet and stable. My soldering skills are weak, didn't want to risk soldering to the main board, but I managed to extract the contacts from the 12V input plug, loosened the crimps just enough to add the fan leads and tightened the crimp tabs again, then re-inserted the contacts into the plug. Cleaned up the wire arrangement with some more cable ties. After re-assembly, I had to remove the side panel to be sure that the fan was running, its that quiet.

comments.text:
That is the best option, unfortunately I have the older version of the board, without the second fan connector. My fan runs continuously when the power is on, but I used the nearly-silent Mini-Kaze fan as suggested in the original mix, and later added another 40mm X 10mm fan on a custom printed left side panel, near the Z-axis stepper, which runs quite hot on long print jobs. With 40mm heatsinks mounted on both steppers, and the two fans, now good circulation and noticeably warm air exhausted on the left side. The combination of passive and active cooling seems to be keeping the steppers happy ...
Already replaced the X-axis bearings with Igus Drylin bushings (you can see them in the first photo above), which are virtually silent in operation and eliminate backlash, and working on a longer ABS bearing block to hold two 8mm Drylin bushings in tandem for each shaft on the Y-axis carriage ...
Also suggest a good quality 10mm dual ball bearing fan for about 10 to 12 bucks, to replace the stock extruder fan, which gets noisy real fast. I wasted at least that much on several cheap fans that rattled and emit over 20db at full speed, a good ball bearing fan will reduce the noise by half ...
Its a bit of work, but it is possible to get the Mini running both cool and quiet ... :-)
comments.author: rjpost942

comments.text:
My printer had an unused fan connector that I could just plug in to. It looks like this:
http://mpselectmini.com/mainboard_cooling_fan
comments.author: micahjoel

comments.text: Sorry I didn't make a video. You can release the contacts in these connectors by gently pressing in on the metal tang on the side of the nylon plug with a toothpick and pulling on the wire. The tang will re-engage when you push the wire back in. I just picked at the part of the crimp over the insulation with a dental tool until it was a little loose, then stripped the fan lead about 3/8', and wrapped the stripped wire around and under the loose crimp tab. Then I re-tightened the crimp with needle-nose pliers, and re-inserted the contact back into the nylon housing until the tang locked again. There are some good videos on YouTube that show how to remove and replace the crimped contacts in this type of connector. I still think its safer than soldering on the board, and worst case you could always just replace the plug with a new one, Amazon has the kits for this. Another possibility is a splice tap like Posi-Tap at https://www.posi-products.com/posiplug.html

title: Campagnolo CS-002 8 speed cassette spacer ring

description.text:
Cassette spacer ring for 8-speed hubs

Keeping old bikes alive with parts that are no longer available (NLA)

This has been tested for fit over cassette, but NOT for thickness. Printing methods can vary the thickness and should be adjusted by the user. Likewise, I can't vouch for the compressiveness of the chosen print plastic. It may take some tweaking to get the proper fit and performance for accurate gear shifting.

I've noticed differences in shifting behavior with original Campy spacers. Only on the third or forth disassembly, reassembly, and 50NM (36.9ft.lbs.) torque on the lock ring did the shifting work perfect.

My first 200+ miles with my 3D printed g-spring carrier (for the rear) demonstrated delayed shifting coming one gear at a time from the 26 down to the 13. It would always take a few more rev of the crank or a slight bump of the thumb trigger. BUT after a full hub rebuild I reassembled the cassette and everything shifted click for gear up and down.

I'm certain that campy's original spacers are not ABS or PLA and this can be problematic until the thickness is dialed in. The design is very simple the recesses I put in are for authenticity but not required. If you want to cook your own spacers, the measured dimensions are as follows:

id 1.39"
od 1.71"
thickness 0.1265"

It may take a few different prints and test runs to learn what works correctly.

Please copy me on you your results if you cook this and get it right. I'd love to know what material, what printer, type of platform (tape on aluminum, glass, etc..) and what thicknesses you ran.
Measured with calipers and rendered with Solidworks

title: Properly Spaced TronXY (X1) Y-Axis Plate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The original acrylic piece that mine came with was cut incorrectly and resulted in very wobbly movement, which meant the printer couldn't print at all. After seeing how many people had a similar issue I decided to just remodel it and replace it entirely with a 3D printed version.

For those of you having a similar issue on the z-axis, unfortunately it's not as easily fixed with a 3D printed replacement. I recommend wrapping your idlers with large heat shrink tubing intended for battery terminals. Electrical tape as a spacer will not work, there cannot be any seam whatsoever. One layer on each idler worked well for me.
Here's what I used. http://www.homedepot.com/p/Heat-Shrink-4-in-Battery-Cable-Identification-Black-Red-4-Pack-HST-ASTBR/205881679

title: Smart Arduino Turret
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This project is a course project for the Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona's Robotics, Language and Learning subject I'm coursing on my Informatics Engineering graduate. I also made available the final sprint report with all the information needed to get this running :)

This is an Arduino-based stationary robot that scans for targets within a short radius and shoots projectiles. The project uses more than one Arduino boards connected through the I2C protocol to handle various tasks. I printed a case for the Arduino uno made by thingiverse user ZygmuntW. The code is hosted in my github repository link, along the instructions to set your own turret up :) The total cost of the project is around 90€ (this is including the approximate cost of the PLA I used to print the parts) depending where you get your parts, and around 40€ extra on top of that if you decide to get the neomatrix and 16 channel PWM I2C board from adafruit instead of a "clone".

The parts list is as follows:

  • Arduino Nano
  • Arduino UNO R3
  • HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor
  • MG996 Servomotor (2x)
  • SG90 Servomotor (2x)
  • 8x8 WS2812B LED matrix
  • M3 x 10 screws
  • M3 x 15 screws
  • M3 nuts
  • M3 brass nuts (for embedding in the larger holes on the base)
  • M2 x 10 screws (to attach the servomotors to the arm, base and tray)
  • 5V power source capable of giving out more than 4A

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A4fSrtVZ4v0

Kite Dihedral
An angle caused by 2 planes to create a wing
The angle of the dihedral is set for optimum stability for a kite
Using spars made from carbon fiber, fiberglass or wooden dowels the kite skin can be attached
Files for the following spar sizes have been produced:

5.5mm vertical spar with a 5.5mm wing spar
5.5mm vertical spar with a 4mm wing spar
5.5mm vertical spar with a 3mm wing spar

7.5mm vertical spar with a 5.5mm wing spar
7.5mm vertical spar with a 4.0mm wing spar

*7.5 to fit a sky-shark carbon spar

4mm vertical spar with a 4mm wing spar
4mm vertical spar with a 3mm wing spar

3mm vertical spar with a 3mm wing spar

All holes are a tight fit on the spars and drilling or reaming out might be required
I found 1.08 % to be the best in the slicer program (cura)
However your results might vary.

To make large fittings the % can be increased in the slicer program

author: shamblatron

description.text:
OK, so, I made this as a joke. One day I was walking with a friend and we found a Shopkins on the ground. Neither of us knew what they were, so we had a hell of a time trying to find out exactly what they were. We had found a Vicki Vanilla toy, but the toys are so small that it was quite a challenge to find them on google. We didn't even realize that it was supposed to be a vial of vanilla (despite its obvious vanilla flower petals). It had a QR code which didn't work with any scanner app we could find. It was weird.

Anyway, after some diligent Googling, we finally figured out what it was, so we got drunk and started watching the ridiculous, so-bad-it's-good web series. Needless to say, Shopkins is now an inside joke with this friend.

Joking aside, this could be a fun spinner for a kid who enjoys the Shopkins toys and/or web series. I recommend painting with acrylics and hitting it with 2-3 coats of polycrylic. Remember to cut/sand away any imperfections before painting/sealing, and please do so in a well ventilated area.

I upgraded the plastic bag I normally use for a first aid kit with a flat box. It's sized to fit the smaller Tegaderm* sizes, which is usually the first (and largest) thing I put in my first aid kits.

The file is designed to be printed with a flexible filament (the two ridges overlap for a secure fit). If you need other sizes or want to print it in other plastics, you can modify the design here

Version 2 of my popular RC plane/wing control horns. The previous version worked great and was virtually indestructible, if you know your slicer settings, anyway. (I had a few comments about how they weren't strong enough, broke easy, from people who don't change settings or know that you even can.)

I printed these with PLA at 210, 40% infill, and (this is important for even MORE strength) 4 PERIMETER layers. Two works ok. Previous version was snapping around 10 ft pounds.

This version widens the riser by 0.25mm on each side (0,5mm thicker total), thickens the re-enforcement base by 0.5mm, and changes the shape of the receiving holes and shrinks the size of the base. I did these changes only for special elevons I made on a wing using balsa tapered in such a way that the previous base was too big. The changes I made for increased strength are for peace of mind on larger wings. The older version weighs less and never failed on me.

title: Testors Aztek Airbrush to 1/4NPT Female Adapter

description.text:
Safety Note:  Air Brushes use pressure ~15-20psi.  Make sure you safely test your part prior to using them.  Start at your regulators lowest pressure setting and work your way up to the desired pressure while keeping a safe distance.  Even at this low pressure a failure could cause injury.  Making an adapter for compressed air that exceeds this is very risky as the part could explode and cause serious injury or death.  You have been warned.

Make sure you use 100% infill

Some (all?) Testor Aztek Airbrushes are designed to work with the compressed cans of air. As far as I can tell the connector is non-standard.

This file creates an adapter that allows a Testor Aztek Airbrush to be connected directly to a 1/4" NTP fitting so it can be used with a compressor.

The OpenSCAD file requires The Maker Garage SCAD Library found here:
https://github.com/themakergarage/tmg_scad_lib

You can also check out the build log here:
http://themakergarage.blogspot.com/2017/06/build-2-aztec-airbrush-adapter.html

Good luck.

title: SurfaceWrite
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is just a first sample of what I think I will call "SurfaceWrite"!

I say this because this method allows you to add your own customized text to ( at least, in theory ) almost any ( "watertight" ) object! Although I have not tried it yet, you should be able to add other items / objects to the "surface" as well!

The interesting part, is that when it comes down to it, this is just a relatively simple "formula", that can be used to calculate a "surface area" for ( almost ) any object.

I say "almost", because I had problems with several models I tried to use. My software informed me that all of them were not "watertight". I was able to "fix" one of them ( the "knob" ) , using www.makeprintable.com , after which the process ran ok.

A major advantage of this approach is that it allows you to use ANY font file / style that is listed under the openscad "Help" menu - "Font List" option.

I am still working on the "include" / "example" scad files. but I just wanted to see what everyone thought!

The following objects were used in this demonstration:

Mug by GoldenRob0t
Published on June 1, 2017
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2359092

knob by epicdoom
Published on June 1, 2017
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2357521

-Fixed an issue that would cause the head to fuse to the body on many resolutions
-Reinforced the wrist joints for stability
-Loosened the tolerances on the leg joints to make the print less likely to fuse the leg joints.
*special thanks to Brandon and Joel, from the MonoPrice Mini Select FB group for printing this and taking the time to give me great feedback to improve my model.

YellowScope is Proud to Announce the YellowScope YS-2. An articulated Print in place robot model. This is one of my first full designs. So, any input is greatly appreciated. I would love to pictures if anyone prints this!

Notes:

I've printed this with a .175 layer height (I have also tested and confirmed .2 works as well), with 3 Layer Walls with best results.

I use some pretty tight clearances for some of the joints so a properly tuned printer is important.

Remove the two build in supports on the back of the Arms

I had to use two small built in supports in order to improve my success rate.to Remove them, simply bend them up and down until they break, This should leave very minimal markings on the print.

This Model was completely Modeled by hand using Fusion 360.

I did take some inspiration from the Makerbot, as well as the Print-in-Place KILLBOT mini so a special thanks to their creators as well.

description.text:
I buy canned tuna in water and really only enjoy it if I can get all the water out before adding my necessary condiments. A few years ago, I had found and bought a tiny plastic disc from an unknown store that was made to make removing the oil or water from tuna basically easy and fool proof. Unfortunately, I misplaced the piece I had bought and have been looking for another but never have been able to locate one.

Finally, one day I hit myself in the head and said...you know...I have a 3D-printer...I can design and make one of my own! Oh yeah, I got started immediately...mainly because I was hungry for Tuna.

After a couple trial and error runs, the final product came out perfect. The piece is big enough to fit a 4-5 ounce can of tuna, enough holes to let the water pass but not the tuna, a little handle to help pull it back out of the can when all is said and done!

I was so happy, I immediately washed the tuna press and used it on a couple cans of tuna for some tuna salad. Simply use a can opener to remove that thin piece of metal from the top of the can (you can't use that to squeeze the water out with anyway!) then drop your tuna press in the can and gently squeeze with your fingers around the edges until enough of the juices have been removed. Use the handle to remove the tuna press and fork or spoon the tuna into whatever bowl you will be using.

Enjoy!

description.text:
Really getting tired of the price of the bigger batteries, i.e. C, D, and 9 volt. So, I decided to make a very simple battery adapter that anyone can use. All ya gotta do is drop a fresh, or not so fresh, AA battery into the center of this adapter and then drop the whole shebang into whatever you want to power with a C battery.

Most AA batteries should fit slightly tight nearing the bottom of the adapter, that is so they do not fall out as you try to place the new C battery into your device.

There's also a handy-dandy signage on the side of the adapter that states 'AA to C Adapter' just in case you forget what the thing is used for.

description.text:
This is probably the last spinner cap you will ever need :-). The spinner cap was created in openSCAD and all aspects of the spinner can be modified. It can be printed with or without a slot, with or without roundovers on the button, the button size, plug size, and so forth can be controlled. I think about using this with a small screw between the buttons - the screw can be screwed into the plastic, or thread inserts can be used.

There are three sample STLs included but this is only a thought regarding what could be generated by this program. Openscad is free. Download it and modify the button plug until you are happy, then make an STL and see how it prints. The difference in the source between the slotted one and the unslotted one is one parameter. Ditto for the double slotted one.

There is a separate set of preview STLs and a separate openSCAD file that is for attaching your caps together with a screw and a nut where the screw and nut are simply screwed in from the outside. The hole in the center goes through and the sample is for a 3mm allen head mchine screw and a nut that has a plastic insert (or a drop of glue). This is abstracted from an older project of mine. It leaves a hole in the center of the spinner cap (perforce) that the new design is supposed to overcome, but you might like it. So I am including it.

Printer:

HE3D K280

Resolution:

0.4 nozzle/0.2 layers.

Infill:

100%

Notes:

If possible, print this without a raft or brim on a smooth surface. The only overhang is the roundover part, and it may not be easy to do, depending on your printers. You can eliminate the roundover and then sand the corners smooth with 100% infill. I suggest a bottom surface (perhaps all surfaces) of concentric lines. Printing with a brim will distort the roundover and make it much less useful.

Screw the plugs together if possible

Of course, you will need to print two of these. Depending on how you plan on holding them together, you might want to install a hex nut into each side (or just one side) and glue it in place. You can either make the hole the right size to screw a piece of threaded rod directly into the plastic, or you can use thread inserts.

My point is that you need to plan on what you are doing and do pre-printing planning. You will need whatever hardware you decide to use. You might just want to print the plugs slightly oversized and slotted, then glue them. If so, you can eliminate the hole simply by setting its size to zero or less. It is all up to you and I hope that this design can support anything you want to do.

The only thing I suggest you don't do is to just press fit the caps into place and leave them that way - especially if you are making this spinner for a kid. Kids need things held in place well, like with screws and nuts. If you want to use a through nut, then use the openSCAD file labeled "external_screw_SpinnerCap.scad" and its matching stls, if needed. This version was initially part of an object that I published as thing 2351891, and it is not part of what I remixed there, so I maintain that this is not a remix. The setup presumes 3mm allen head screws, and hex nuts, I used nuts with plastic inserts but you can use plain hex nuts. The downside is that the fingerpads are thicker, and they have the big hole in the center. I guess I decided to add these to this file as a last sort of thought - as I tried to think about what I might want that I had not included.

Design

I looked at thingiverse and there were a number of spinner caps but none of them was quite what I needed. I wanted caps that could be attached together with hidden screws - my thought was to use an allen key or to use a cut off bolt - and either use threaded inserts or screw straight into the plastic. But all of the caps made some other assumption. I tried to make no assumptions when I designed this. If you find I made an assumption that stops you from using this cap, let me know and I will try again.

When you think about design in openSCAD, you simply have to break the item down into its component shapes, then declare those shapes.

This item is four cylinders (one for the button, one for the shelf, one for the plug and one for the hole. Obviously, three of those are added, one is subtracted. They are placed in specific spatial relationships, and that results in this spinner cap.

There is a sphere that is optionally used to round the edges of the button.

There is a cube that is used to cut the slot in the plug, if you say you want a cube.

This only took me a couple hours to do - real time, including all refinements, and so forth. I did this because I wanted to make two plugs that could be screwed together with a small piece of threaded rod for my granddaughter's spinner. She wanted pink plugs. Se had lost one, since it had fallen off and also needed new bearings.

All of the names I use in this start with BC - so that the source can be easily incorporated into another thing. Please respect the license if you do so.

I have included a part of a file that I originally published as a separate thing. That is the file that generates the through hole version, with countersunk hardware. It might be possible to use one through hole cap, and one cap designed to be screwed into. Mix and match as you choose.

print_settings.Notes:: The tolerances are extremely tight and possible won't work well if your printer isn't calibrated correctly, so if it doesn't work try printing 1% or 2% bigger. Also, for the main body, try to have the frames come to the top, meaning that there will be an overhang. However this overhang is easily closed, so support isn't necessary. But obviously if you want to use it I can't stop you :)

title: Phenakistoscope Fidget Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
https://youtu.be/f1-ezPO54SA

I have been messing around with these fidget spinners for a while now as I have made several design despite not uploading them anywhere, partly because there were a lot of them anyways and I hadn't made anything spectacularly different. However every time I made one I thought of was I could make my spinners different. I tried spray painting, messing with different shapes and patters etc. But today I had the idea to turn one one of these to a phenakistoscope, as it seemed like a pretty good idea. So what I did was I just searched for a gif, which then I separated to its frames using an online separator. So now get your favourite gif and turn it into a fidget spinner! Also, feel free to modify the design as you wish to accommodate more frames etc.

Disclaimer: You can't see it with your eyes and will need a phone camera or something along those lines. The video you see was shot on an iPhone 7 in the slow-mo setting, without it actually slowing the video down.
The working principle of this isn't exactly the same as a phenakistoscope but it is pretty similar.

MakerBot

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

No

Doesn't Matter

0.2

%50

Notes:

The tolerances are extremely tight and possible won't work well if your printer isn't calibrated correctly, so if it doesn't work try printing 1% or 2% bigger. Also, for the main body, try to have the frames come to the top, meaning that there will be an overhang. However this overhang is easily closed, so support isn't necessary. But obviously if you want to use it I can't stop you :)

Images

As I said in the summary, for the images what I did was search for a running man gif, which I then separated on a online web site ( https://ezgif.com/split ). The website is actually pretty good and labels each picture with its frame name. Than after I downloaded the pictures from the website I cropped them to 1.5cm by 1.5cm. The rest is pretty straight forward, where you just print and cut the frames before sticking them to the main body using a regular glue stick in order.

The 8 frame gif I used.

description.text: Custom hex spinner I made. I used PLA for printing and changed colors a few times during printing for a better effect. Heatbed 60, Nozzle 210.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.17

Infill:

30

Notes:

Heatbed 60, Nozzle 210 - Using PLA

The object consists of three sections: A left side half pipe with roll in ramp, a center half pipe, and a right side half pipe with roll in ramp. The first file contains one of each section of ramp. Additionally, each section is also available as a separate STL(usefull for smaller print beds, or to expand the half pipe in length). To print a complete halfpipe you will two copies of each section. Additionally, the center section can be printed on its own to extend the size of the quarter/half pipe. Each ramp piece features realistic coping, and a safety rail, so it looks and functions like the real thing!

The default print orientation is for each piece to lay on its side(see first image) and all three sections are designed to be arranged on the print bed as show which will fit on a 200mm x 200mm build plate. If you have a smaller bed, or prefer to print one section at a time, you will find that the additional files contain just the named section of pipe(Left, Right, Center) but should also be printed laying down as pictured. This orientation allows printing without supports. Another advantage is that the layer lines will be vertical when the piece is used in its normal orientation, which will allow for a much smoother ride for the fingerboard. Though the object is solid and relatively big in volume, I left it solid as opposed to hollowing it out so that no supports will be needed inside the object either. It should print just fine with a very low infill percentage, as long as you make sure to solid fill a few extra top and bottom layers, which will also help with rigidity while in use. Additionally I would recommend using several shell layers which will help the top curve of the drop in ramps, and ensure that all the ramp faces remain rigid.

Estimated time and material to print a single section: 7 hours at 70 grams
Estimated time and material to print complete 6 section halfpipe: 42 hours at 420 grams
Approx. size of each section is: 120mm x 130mm x 90mm

*Time and material estimates based on a print speed of 100mm per second, infill at 10%, Top/Bottom/Shell thickness at 1.2mm, a .4 nozzle at .1mm layer height, and no adhesion or support options on.
The material folding support is used for the 2020 profile

comments.text: I love your model man.. unfortunately I can't print it it it's current state. Your design choice to have the odd rod in the middle for the flippers, while also having a flipper dangling over air, and the inside not actually be hollow means this thing is a nightmare to slice. The only way to print the free hanging flipper is to use so much support that it ruins it, and the middle having those weird walls (instead of being solid and allowing the slicer to determine how it is filled) means the slicer has to print supports inside - and they fail.

Make your PVC marshmallow gun safer for your kids to use!  Prevents choking on marshmallows through the use of a breech loader.

First, you need a marshmallow gun. At the Maker Faire 2012, I saw the design at HowToons. He said we could buy the kit for $10, or go to the store and pay half that amount. I opted for the latter, and here is the BOM: (1) length of 1/2" PVC (I bought 4ft)
(2) 1/2" PVC T joints, slip fit
(2) 1/2" PVC slip fit caps
(2) 1/2" PVC 90 degree elbows, slip fit Just cut and assemble to look like the photo I uploaded. Takes less than 1 minute to make if you have those handy PVC cutters! Now print the parts, and snap the cover onto the breech. Press the breech onto the end of the gun. Slide open the cover, drop in a marshmallow, close the cover, and fire! The mouthpiece makes the gun much more comfortable to use, and the features in the air path prevent the marshmallow from getting sucked backward and into your throat (ask me how I know this). The breech was designed to be printed without support material (mouthpiece should be at the top when you print). So make sure you set your print parameters correctly. The chamfer is 45 degrees.

comments.text:
Does this shoot mini marshmallows?
Thanks!
comments.author: JHROX1234

comments.text: Yes this shoots mini-marshmallows. If you want to shoot larger ones you would need larger pvc, loader and breath.

title: RoboCAT Lowrider Antenna holder and PDB Cover

description.text:
Ok, so not exactly a remix but a second and third print made to go along with the original lowrider by Diymik. This is the antenna holder and a PDB cover. The antenna holder holds both the video transmitter antenna and the antennas from a FRSKY sbus receiver. The video transmitter antenna will require a SMA extension cable. Sorry i did not take more photos. I'll see what I can do to get some to upload. The PDB cover mounts between the bottom plate and the re-purposed top plate (now the bottom plate) since I mounted my flight controller in the space typically taken up by the PDB. Presently this antenna mount requires you to use smaller 5 inch props. I'm going to redesign it a bit to move the antennas up so that 6 inch props are an option.

Enjoy

title: Nissan Leaf Strut Cap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So the standard strut cap that is in the Nissan Leaf is apparently prone to still letting water in. The 3rd 4th and 5th photo show the original cap and the water that is let in. It stops short of the edge of the gasket and water seep in the side.

I've drawn up a new cap that extends down the side to make sure that all the water is shed off outside the gasket.

Should be much better at keeping water out but time will tell.

Original post here about the problem: http://www.mynissanleaf.com/viewtopic.php?f=30&t=21723

As I understand it, this should also fit similar Nissan models like the Juke.

Update: added a model with more of a lip for better retention but it may not fit on your cap depending on the accuracy of your printer. Can try both with different scaling factors.

If someone has an original cap on hand and can measure the dimensions of the clips for me that would be really useful....

description.text:
The Zenfone 2 has Dual SIM and lately the SIM in Slot 1 would move out and disconnect during normal use. So I designed this to add a bit of tension to both SIM cards

For Single SIM I scaled up the Model:
X axis stays the same
Y axis +1mm (+6%)
Z axis + 0,5mm (+50%)

I did not test the Single Slot version, if it's too short increase the Y axis by another 0.5mm ( ~3%)
I increased the thickness so the tensioner shouldn't be able to move into the unused SIM Slot.

After this was printed, I cut out another rectangle that was 12.5 by 6 inches. I then glued the two pieces together.

If not match, you need align the printer and start again.

description.text:
This is a similar box I've seen around, however I found the two that I printed the little lid catches broke off. So I designed my own in Fusion 360 with a tight tolerance lid that doesn't need the catches. This was modelled very quickly, but I'm very happy with how it turned out.

The ellipse openings allow the UNO logo to show through removing all doubt about what's inside, and the lower opening allows for easy removable of the deck for shuffling. I rounded the corners on the sharp edges too a little as the previous one I printed had sharp 90 degree corners that my kids would complain about.

An easy Sunday afternoon print that is much better than the small cardboard box the game usually comes in.

title: table corner protective hands
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
when my wife asked me to print some protection corners for our glass table, i searched a lot but only found boring stuff. so i had the idea to do something cooler... ;-)
now, what do you do, when you protect your child at the table? you use your hands...
i found a perfect hand from danowall (thanks a lot for it). i sized it a bit down, cut away the wall part and puzzled a while to fit the glass table into it.
now, it should even stay in place without any glue, as the hand goes a bit around the glass to the bottom.
I fitted it to my 12mm glass table.

description.text:
This spool filament clip is designed to fit the standard Esun spools. It snaps onto the spool edge easily and holds onto the lip where it can be moved along the rail. The filament easily fits into the groove with a satisfying snap and holds well. I made a lead in so it's easy for you to snap in the filament. It's a low enough profile that it hasn't caught on anything... I've got it on around 15 spools so it's well tested... this is design iteration 4. Enjoy!

BTW, if anyone wants this design made to fit other spools with a rail then just post the dimensions (rail width & height, lip distance from outer edge & depth of lip, plus whether the lip is one sided or both) and I'll do my best to add it?

author: kiiraklis94

description.text:
I really liked the Artichoke Lamp Shade design by gCreate but it was too large to print on my setup. Downscaling was no option for me since I wanted a large printed lamp to display in my living room. I decided to edit the .stl file and cut the lamp into smaller pieces (top and bottom, both in thirds) to print separately. To be able to print the cut parts without high support structures I made some small modifications to the bottom of some of the 'leafs'. I also added a small protrusion to help with aligning the parts when glueing them back together.

I printed the lamp in Colorfabb woodfill which always prints easily on my setup, even with bridges and large overhangs. Moreover, the result always looks amazing. An additional advantage of printing the lamp in separate parts is that if this rather difficult print fails, only a smaller piece is wasted instead of a 10+ hour print.

Printed with a raft, with Woodfill I used a 0.25mm layer height, 10% infill. Only use support for the underside of the lowest leaf. Glue the parts together with epoxy glue.

title: Anet A8 12 mm Right Rear Inductive Probe Mount

description.text:
This inductive sensor holder for the Anet A8 is intended for use with an auto level set up. It will fit a standard 12 mm diameter probe. Simply remove the M4 bolts on the extruder carriage frame and bolt this in with it, you may have to find some longer M4 screws.

Similar to the Prusa I3 Mk2 Design.

Advantages of this design:

  • The auto level sensor is not disturbed when removing the fan and heat sink to sort a blockage
  • The sensor is able to reach a larger area of the bed for more accurate probing
  • It is mounted directly to the extruder carriage frame so does not easily move around thanks to its 4 mounting holes (compared to most other designs that use 2).

Handy Information:

  • Sensor offset is X: +61 mm Y: +11 mm (see diagram)

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Printed in no name orange PLA with great results. 30 mm/s print speed, 50 mm/s travel speed. Fan 70% (don't use fan if printing in ABS).

Sensor offset from extruder

After printing, you may need to sand a small amount from around the lower left hole in order to get it to fit behind the aluminium hot end block that the heat sink connects to (I used a dremel). I have left this extra material in so you can adjust to your printer. The tight fit is partly what gives it strength. Don't worry, you cant see this bit anyway, so it doesn't have to look stunning.

title: Anet A8 Laser Cut Acryllic Power Supply & Motherboard Case

description.text:
This is a very neat way to tidy up all the electronics of the Anet A8. It has been laser cut in 3 mm black acrylic. I painted the engravings by using spray paint on a brush, painting fully over the engraving, removing the excess with paper towel and cleaning up the residue with a cloth soaked in cellulose thinners. This creates a very sleek look and the whole thing looks like it was there from factory. Glue all the pieces together with superglue in the joins apart from the front which screws on.

I added a beeper to the Anet A8 using the spare "LED_PIN". You can see this as well as other pin mappings for the anet v1.0 board in this thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2103748

I configured my firmware to feature a beeper and defined the beeper pin in pins.h appropriately. I used this piezo beeper module: http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/162273401946?_trksid=p2057872.m2748.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT
If you want any extra information on how to add this feature or using this spare pin for any other function, just leave a comment.

I also added an emergency stop button using a simple push to make switch connected between the ground and reset pins of "J3". This works really well and stops any moves / heaters immediately. Great for bed crashes!

There is also space for a 40 mm fan.

One switch on the PSU case is for mains power and one can be used for lighting or something else. The hole for the socket will accept a standard IEC socket.

You will have to remove the mainboard and screw the case behind it and the same with the power supply.

IMPORTANT NOTE: The power supply case is designed for a upgraded 33 amp power supply (the one with the fan) and not stock 20 amp one. They have different dimensions. The motherboard case should work on all Anet A8's.

Disclaimer: I take no responsibility for any harm that may arise as a result of making the 220/110v connections. Ensure you are competent to handle such voltages and do so at your own risk.

How To Assemble

1) Fasten all the pieces together "dry" first, connecting them with masking tape to ensure everything is in the correct place and the correct way round.

2) Flow superglue into the join from the inside of the case and wipe away any excess on the outside before it leaves a mark. DO NOT GLUE THE FRONT PANEL ON - IT ATTACHES LATER WITH SCREWS. Remove the masking tape.

3) Remove the motherboard and power supply and pass all the wires through the holes.

4) For the power supply case, drill 3 mm holes in the places where they line up with the holes in the frame.

5) Screw the motherboard and power supply back on with the back plate trapped behind.

6) Connect all the cables again.

7) Insert the switches and buzzer module into the correct places and connect them up.

8) Attach both front panels with M3 screws.

A lot of time, patience and prototyping!

Making this case involved measuring EVERYTHING with calipers and a ruler and writing everything down and in drawings. Once I finally had a design, I printed it on card and cut every line with a Stanley knife and stuck it all together with masking tape to check it all lined up. After a few adjustments to make it work, I laser cut it in 3 mm acrylic.

author: mcapilot

description.text:
This is a GT2 belt based reduction gear for MPCNC X and Y steppers. Standard A4988 drivers are fairly weak that might result in steppers skipping steps. Shown here 1:4 reduction virtually eliminates this issue.

The design allows to use either NEMA17 or NEMA23 steppers.

X and Y part differ only in backplate. The one for Y direction has a mount for an angled support of Z chain. Therefore one of gear_reduction_y_back_plate_f.stl needs to be printed mirrored.The main motor mount is the same. The gears are 80T and 20T. This can be changed to your liking.

The pulleys (80T and 20T) are built using this links:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1812136
The project is included for you convinience

Parts needed:
GT2 belt (100 teeth as shown. 96 teeth would work best)
handful of M3 nuts and bolts for pulley mounting
6-32 x 1.5 - 24pcs (back plate mount)
6-32 x 3/4 - 4pc (angle mount)
6-32 nuts - 28pcs
5mm x 50mm shaft - 4pcs
Bolts/nuts to mount steppers - 16pcs
625ZZ bearings - 8pcs

The 5x50mm shaft is made from 100mm RC helicopter shaft available from multiple places. Cut it in half with a diamond cutting wheel (dremel). Add flats for easy pulley mount with M3 screws.

SKP design files are included.

comments.text: Is this suitable for 25mm rod version?
comments.author: kev1990n

comments.text: Nope. It's american. That's why I provided SKP files so people can change it if they want to.
